title: Measles outbreaks driven by difficulty in getting vaccinations, not anti-vaxxers, warn health experts
text:
The rise in measles is being fueled by a shortage of nurses, health workers and difficulties in getting GP appointments, rather than anti-vaccination lobbyists, public health experts have warned.

There were 966 confirmed cases of measles in 2019, nearly four times higher than the previous year.

But although Matt Hancock, the health secretary, has blamed anti-vaxxers for stoking public fears about the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) jab, experts said many parents simply could not get their children vaccinated even when they wanted to.
